ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Great course on special topics in water -- excellent opportunity to discuss current research areas/sectors of water resource management with two highly regarded professors!
Great class- taught interesting material in much needed detail.

The class is a bit misnamed, as is the syllabus, we didn't really talk much about watercycles or processes, but we did learn a lot about shale gas, energy, hydrology, and virtual water. It was an interesting mesh of topics.I would have liked to hear more about the two professor's research and how it related to what we discussed in class. I think reading the literature in these areas and discussing it was helpful for those of us who were interested but that's all we did. All of the class discussions were really student led.
I really enjoyed the class and learned a lot about subjects I was not very familiar with.
The discussion and classroom dynamic made it the perfect forum to talk about sometimes controversial topics. Great learning experience!

So I was a tiny bit mislead by the title of the course - but I figured that out on the first day and decided to stick it out. I gained a ton of really good knowledge, but I am not sure how applicable it will be to my professional career. I will be able to talk extensively about fracking and virtual water however. All in all a great course that stimulated a lot of thought and discussion. If I have one regret it is that I felt we often got lost in the details - in my opinion there could have been more effort to focus on the big picture and policy implications rather than one tiny flaw in one part of one guys argument.
Allowed for in depth exploration of new and important topics.
Reading the literature in depth on two very interesting and high-profile areas and determining for ourselves and with our peers our thoughts on the information and the topics.

I really appreciated two professors taking the time to carefully go through journal articles with us and help us to understand the way they analyze arguments and data presented in articles. Because of this strong feature of the course, I felt this was an indispensable course for those wanting to better understand how to interpret and critique journal articles. This should be a fundamental skill acquired in a masters program so I hope that more of these seminar type courses are offered.
The course taught me to read scientific literature carefully and critically.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The title... it is definitely not about Watersheds... perhaps Virtual Fracking is a better option.
Organization - materials for class to be distributed through classesv2 earlier
The organization and instruction of the course, and maybe add a bit of breadth in the class with the depth. LIke some watercycles and processes lectures. Just a few.

Although the literature on these subjects is still a work in progress, some of the readings could be improved. Many assigned readings presented a lot of the same information, and there could be some adjustments made to gather new sources. However, as new material is available and with the improved knowledge of the instructors on the topics, the class could easily continue to evolve and become a solid foundation course for students interested in water resources. I also think a guest speaker or two would help break up the presentations every week.

To improve the course, it would be good if the progression of articles in the virtual water portion of the course was streamlined to make a bit more sense in terms of building on background information. Also, it may have been useful if some of the assignments were more completely thought about prior to being assigned to ensure they were doable.
none

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: They were always available!
great.
From a scale of one to ten, one being poor, ten excellent. 7
Great.
Both professors were available when I asked for help.
instructors were very responsive to questions in class and during office hours

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great to learn about topics that are not necessarily covered in the water resource management curriculum -- helpful to gain insight from Jim and Pete to see how academia is responding to these issues.
it doesn't really. But I'll do well in dinner conversations about fracking and water footprints!
Very helpful in understanding these hot topics.

I am taking a broad range of courses at FES but am generally trying to balance my social science perspective with the environmental sciences. I feel that this class forced me to think outside of my comfort zone in a way that has really pushed me to refine my critical thinking.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I did not have a well developed background in the topics and I figured if I want pursue a career in WRM, I have to at least have working knowledge of shale gas development and virtual water.
personal interest.
The topics were interesting and science based.
Very relevant to what I want to study.
To learn about new water topics and gather knowledge on water resource issues.
I took this course to learn more about the science of hydrofracking and virtual water. This course accomplished that.
Because of the subject matter.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes -- It was definitely worthwhile.
yup.
Yes.
Not exactly, but it's okay, it was valuable.
Yes.
The course was much more of a challenge than I had anticipated. Although I did not do very well in the class I learned more in this class than I did for most of my other courses.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes! I now can hold a graduate level conversation on these topics!
yup. probably more - I was amazing engaged, largely I think because of the heavy amount of student participation.
Yes.
Some, yes. I thought the latter half would be more practical.
Yes - the course provided me the knowledge I needed on two water-related subjects I knew little about.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good way to keep everyone in the class engaged!
got to hang with my boy Dave.
Discussing scientific papers with a classmate.
Did not participate in a work group. Unsure what this refers to.

All group work has its advantages and disadvantages. Advantages: sharing the work, receiving new opinions/views on topics, learning new things, working with someone new you've never worked with; Disadvantages: depending on someone's schedule, risk of being partnered with a 'slacker' of sortsOverall, I think the group work was effective and could continue to evolve in this type of course.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Suggest topics you want to learn about!
Take the class.
Class is virtual fracking. First half of class about fracking, second half of class about virtual water. Very helpful and interesting if you're interested in these topics.

Read the assignments and come up with questions beforehand. Sometimes it is hard to come up with questions, and in this case it is okay to state an opinion here and there. But please do not bogart the conversation.
I would highly recommend any seminar course taught by these professors as they will help you to learn to better read, interpret, and critique journal articles.
A background in science
